## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 450, 88]]<|/det|>
Jacob throws three coins at the same time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 87, 826, 106]]<|/det|>
The first coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 107, 828, 125]]<|/det|>
The second coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{4}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 127, 826, 145]]<|/det|>
The third coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{5}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 144, 556, 161]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) is the number of heads obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 174, 148, 192]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 173, 363, 192]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X = 2) = \frac{3}{20}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 174, 920, 192]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 203, 917, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 484, 148, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 484, 534, 502]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 484, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 917, 935]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Last year, an online store sold a large number of computers. \(55\%\) of the computers were made by company \(F,\) \(30\%\) were made by company \(G\) and \(15\%\) were made by company \(H.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 117, 804, 136]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 3 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the 3 customers bought computers all made by different companies. [1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 915, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 428, 814, 447]]<|/det|>
A random sample of 12 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 918, 478]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that fewer than 10 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 918, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 915, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 823, 88]]<|/det|>
<pre>A random sample of 140 customers who each bought a computer from this store is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that more than 24 of these customers bought a computer made by company \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The lengths of 250 leaves of a certain type of plant are measured, correct to the nearest centimetre. The results are summarised in the table below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 119, 850, 170]]<|/det|>

Frequency182860724824

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 527, 88]]<|/det|>
38% of these leaves are of length \(k \text{cm}\) or more.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 470, 120]]<|/det|>
Use your graph to find an estimate for \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 144, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 259, 638, 276]]<|/det|>
Calculate an estimate for the mean length of these 250 leaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 259, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 292, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Eddie has 16 toy cars, of which 8 are white, 5 are black and 3 are silver. He places all the cars in a bag and selects three of them at random, without replacement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 611, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that all three cars are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, when the 3 cars are selected, at least one car is white and at least one car is black. [4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 915, 952]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[826, 945, 915, 961]]<|/det|>
[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
The mass of peaches sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean \(65.8 \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(9.6 \mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the mass of peaches sold on any given day is between \(56\mathrm{kg}\) and \(75\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 163, 917, 938]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
<pre>The mass of cherries sold per day in a supermarket is normally distributed with mean \(72.4 \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). It is known that on \(10\%\) of days less than \(59.1 \mathrm{kg}\) of cherries are sold.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 314, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 120, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 479]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 490, 432, 507]]<|/det|>
<pre>The supermarket is open 7 days a week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 146, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than \(59.1 \mathrm{kg}\) of cherries are sold is the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 660, 148, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 660, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, in a randomly chosen week, the first day on which less than \(59.1 \mathrm{kg}\) of cherries are sold is before the fifth day of the week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
Alissa has 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles. The books look similar except for their colour. There are 3 blue books, 2 red books, 2 yellow books, 1 orange book, 1 purple book and 1 green book.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 908, 151]]<|/det|>
Alissa places the books in a row on her shelf. She is only interested in the arrangement of the colours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 685, 183]]<|/det|>
How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 917, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 146, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books in which the 3 blue books are together, but the 2 yellow books are not next to each other?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
How many different colour arrangements are there of the 10 books with exactly 4 books between the 2 yellow books?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 918, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 917, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 427, 793, 445]]<|/det|>
<pre>Alissa selects 4 books from her 10 different books from the series Squares and Circles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different selections if the 4 books include at least 1 red book, at most 1 blue book and exactly 1 yellow book.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 918, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
